comments.raw_text:
Heise has recently replaced their social network "Like" buttons by a two-click solution. The first turns the button on (associated with all the privacy problems involved), the second performs the regular button function. Using this technique, users visiting their sites do not transfer any data to Facebook and others. Only if they really want to use one of the buttons, they reveal any data.

We discussed this briefly in the security channel and believe it could be worth investigating if a browser based opt-in function doing this would be practical and useful.

Here's the reference to their article about it (in german though): http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Facebook-Co-2-Klicks-fuer-mehr-Datenschutz-1335091.html

comments.text: The "Web Intents" proposal is yet another way to get at this. The site can have a generic "Share" or "Like" button that when pressed notifies whoever the user has set up for that function. Some of the Web APIs mhanson was talking about recently are yet another way to expose this in a 3rd-party-neutral way. All great for users, but likely unpopular with the Facebooks and Twitters of the world who might pressure sites not to do that (similar to how FB pressured Heise in the article above).
